title: Whitelist for nofollow rule?
body: Is it possible to whitelist my own domain from the nofollow rule as seen here https://github.com/vmg/redcarpet/issues/69

title: Unordered list item interpreted as order list item
body:
This issue was found during the investigations made for http://www.redmine.org/issues/21181

The following syntax:
```
1.  this is a list item with two child items.
    -  first child
    -  second child
1.   another item in the same list.
-  text wrongly interpreted as ordered list item

1. last item of the ordered list
```

generates:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5037739/38161996-b399747a-34e1-11e8-81d7-8808f0273a39.png)

I'm not sure which is the expected behaviour (if the last item of the ordered list should be really the last item or should be the first item from a new ordered list), but I'm almost sure that the list item "text wrongly interpreted as ordered list item" should not be interpreted as ordered list.

title: Incorrect parsing un-indented HTML fragment
body:
I came across an issue parsing an un-indented HTML fragment, where the parser seems to be incorrectly treating part of the HTML as a block of paragraph-text (wrapped in a `

` tag and quote-escaped). Here's a minimal-repro test case where the issue should be self-explanatory: ``` $ ruby -rredcarpet -e "puts Redcarpet::Markdown.new(Redcarpet::Render::HTML).render(ARGF.read)" <

MD

``` Compare against: - [`commonmarker`](https://github.com/gjtorikian/commonmarker): ``` $ ruby -rcommonmarker -e "puts CommonMarker.render_html(ARGF.read)" <
MD
``` - [`kramdown`](https://github.com/gettalong/kramdown): ``` $ ruby -rkramdown -e "puts Kramdown::Document.new(ARGF.read).to_html" <
MD
``` - [`bluecloth`](https://github.com/ged/bluecloth): ``` $ ruby -rbluecloth -e "puts BlueCloth.new(ARGF.read).text" <
MD
```

title: Email addresses containing underscore and surrounded by <> are filtered out when filter_html is enabled
body:
A Redmine user reported that [Markdown doesn't recognize some email addresses](http://www.redmine.org/issues/23019). I've added two test cases to illustrate the reported problem. Unfortunately, I don't have the required skills to fix the issue. ```ruby def test_filter_html_doesnt_filter_email_addresses_surrounded_by_tags markdown = "" output = render(markdown, with: [:filter_html, :autolink]) assert_equal "

abc@example.org

", output end ``` ```ruby def test_filter_html_doesnt_filter_email_addresses_surrounded_by_tags_and_containing_underscore markdown = "" output = render(markdown, with: [:filter_html, :no_intra_emphasis, :autolink]) assert_equal "

a_bc@example.org

", output end ``` The second test fails because is considered somehow an HTML tag and it is filtered out. ``` /vagrant/redcarpet/test/html_render_test.rb:54:in `test_filter_html_doesnt_filter_email_addresses_surrounded_by_tags_and_containing_underscore' 51: markdown = "" 52: output = render(markdown, with: [:filter_html, :no_intra_emphasis, :autolink]) 53: => 54: assert_equal "

a_bc@example.org

", output 55: end 56: 57: def test_that_no_image_flag_works <"

a_bc@example.org

"> expected but was <""> Failure: test_filter_html_doesnt_filter_email_addresses_surrounded_by_tags_and_containing_underscore(HTMLRenderTest) .......................... Finished in 0.30313018 seconds. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 131 tests, 190 assertions, 1 failures, 0 errors, 0 pendings, 0 omissions, 0 notifications 99.2366% passed ```

title: What's the best way to define your own header method?
body:
I followed the instructions [here](https://github.com/vmg/redcarpet#and-you-can-even-cook-your-own) to implement my own header method. I want to generate headers with a pretty anchor link so users can easily link to parts of my markdown document. Something like this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/277474/33566663-8623d192-d8d5-11e7-8229-4404e034dd1f.png)

(I'm setting `with_toc_data` to true so I can also generate a table of contents)

When overriding the header method, I need to include an `id` attribute in the generated `<h1>` tag. I want that `id` to match the links that will be generated by `Redcarpet::Render::HTML_TOC`, so I need to hook into the [`rndr_header_anchor`](https://github.com/vmg/redcarpet/blob/f441dec42a5097530328b20e9d5ed1a025c600f7/ext/redcarpet/html.c#L273-L319) (called by the [`rndr_header`](https://github.com/vmg/redcarpet/blob/f441dec42a5097530328b20e9d5ed1a025c600f7/ext/redcarpet/html.c#L322) method which I'm trying to override). I couldn't find any way to call the `rndr_header_anchor` method myself from Ruby, so I've resorted to this hack:

```ruby
# This is annoying. Redcarpet implements this id generation logic in C, and
# AFAIK doesn't provide any hook for calling this method directly from Ruby.
# See C code here: https://github.com/vmg/redcarpet/blob/f441dec42a5097530328b20e9d5ed1a025c600f7/ext/redcarpet/html.c#L273-L319
def header_anchor(text)
  Nokogiri::HTML(Redcarpet::Markdown.new(Redcarpet::Render::HTML.new(with_toc_data: true)).render("# #{text}")).css('h1')[0]["id"]
end

def header(text, header_level)
  if @options[:with_toc_data]
    id = header_anchor(text)
    text = anchorable(text, id)
  end

  "<h#{header_level}>#{text}</h#{header_level}>\n"
end
```

Is there a better way to achieve what I'm trying to do here?

title: Table of contents generation doesn't work when there are images in the headers
body:
Input markdown: ``` # some text ![img](https://example.com) ``` Generated TOC: ``` irb(main):003:0> puts Redcarpet::Markdown.new(Redcarpet::Render::HTML_TOC.new(with_toc_data: true)).render("# some text ![img](https://example.com)")
  • some text ![img](https://example.com)
=> nil ``` Generated HTML: ``` irb(main):004:0> puts Redcarpet::Markdown.new(Redcarpet::Render::HTML.new(with_toc_data: true)).render("# some text ![img](https://example.com)")

some text

=> nil ``` As you can see, the generated HTML has `h1 id="some-text"`, but the generated TOC links to `#some-text-img-https-example-com`. I tried this out with links (rather than images), and that seems to work fine. I dug into the relevant C code a bit, and it looks like this works for links because we define a [`toc_link` here](https://github.com/vmg/redcarpet/blob/f441dec42a5097530328b20e9d5ed1a025c600f7/ext/redcarpet/html.c#L765), but we don't define a [`toc_image` here](https://github.com/vmg/redcarpet/blob/f441dec42a5097530328b20e9d5ed1a025c600f7/ext/redcarpet/html.c#L763). We need to actually render the images so `toc_header` receives HTML tags that can be ignored when calling `rndr_header_anchor`. If there's interest, I can try to put together a PR that fixes this.

title: Use Ruby's `ruby_xmalloc`
body:
Right now, memory allocations in this library are done via `malloc`, however, we are not checking for `NULL` pointers in all of them, like in: https://github.com/vmg/redcarpet/pull/633#issuecomment-343580107

In case `malloc` fails, the received pointer is going to eventually be dereferenced, and this will cause the Ruby process to crash.

This PR replaces `malloc` usage by `ruby_xmalloc` (as well as their `free` counterparts), as it checks the allocation result. In case the allocation fails it will raise an error.

What do you think, @robin850? ðŸ˜„ 

cc/ @dylanahsmith

title: Hard wrap does not work inside indented lists
body:
Consider this markdown:

```
1. Parent item
    
    1. Child item
    This should have a line break before it when hard_wrap is on.
```

Even when `hard_wrap: true` is set, this renders as:

```
1. Parent item
    
    1. Child item This should have a line break before it when hard_wrap is on.
```

title: Unintuitive / broken(?) handling of multiple paragraphs and sublists inside a list item
body:
**Problematic markdown:**
The following markdown is problematic in redcarpet:

```
- my paragraph 1
  which has lots of interesting text

  - sub list item 1
  - sub list item 2

  my paragraph 2
  which also has lots of text

- item 2
```
**Expected behavior:**
Everything above "item 2" is for a human very obviously part of the entire first list item.
This is also how GitHub renders it:

- my paragraph 1
  which has lots of interesting text

  - sub list item 1
  - sub list item 2

  my paragraph 2
  which also has lots of text

- item 2

**Actual (buggy) behavior:**
However, redcarpet in the version used in GitLab gives this result:

- my paragraph 1
  which has lots of interesting text

  - sub list item 1
  - sub list item 2

my paragraph 2
which also has lots of text

- item 2

**Summary:**
Therefore, I suggest this behavior is changed because it doesn't make much sense compared to how it appears to a human, and because the notable site GitHub also interprets this in a much more sensible way. This is the GitLab downstream report where I discovered the behavior: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ce/issues/35456

title: Withspace in front of lines
body:
I am making a poetry website and some poems start with whitespace in front of the line.

I know I can add ` ` but it's off course way better if I can just use spaces or maybe an excluded symbol like `~` or whatever. 

Could I use an option for that. Or write my own custom method that converts back and forth my special symbol between a ` ` and a "whitespace" in my forms / show?

Thanks.

title: Inconstant List Indentation
body:
Pull request for issue #615 

* Create test to replicate issue #615 
* Correct improper indentation handling by using current indentation to limit scan on later levels

title: Inconstant List Indentation
body:
### Input ```md - Item 1 - Item 2 - Item 3 - Item 4 - Item 5 ``` ### Output ```html
  • Item 1
    • Item 2
      • Item 3
      • Item 4
        • Item 5
``` ![screen shot 2017-04-06 at 1 24 30 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3108007/24769514/6eaa9e8c-1acc-11e7-856b-18c1207db4b2.png) ### Expected Output Each bullet with more indentation than the previous bullet should start a child list. ### References https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ce/issues/3470

title: Relative links rendered with incorrect directory path
body:
#### Expected behavior

When adding a link with a relative path, I expect it to render display and link to the directory path I indicated. 

`[/v3/orders/{order_id}/transactions](/api/v3/openapi-v3.html#gettransactions/)` should provide `https://domain.com/api/v3/openapi-v3.html#gettransactions`. 

#### Actual behavior

Links that contain `.html` instead of a relative directory path strip the part of the url so the link for `[/v3/orders/{order_id}/transactions](/api/v3/openapi-v3.html#gettransactions/)` becomes `https://domain.com/v3/openapi-v3.html#gettransactions`. 

#### Steps to reproduce

This above behavior has been seen with [middleman](https://github.com/middleman/middleman) with [Slate](https://github.com/lord/slate). 

Attempts to troubleshoot have included adding a trailing slash and removing it or changing the placement. 

- `[/v3/orders/{order_id}/transactions](/api/v3/openapi-v3.html/#gettransactions)`
- `[/v3/orders/{order_id}/transactions](/api/v3/openapi-v3.html#gettransactions)`
- `[/v3/orders/{order_id}/transactions](/api/v3/openapi-v3.html#gettransactions/)`

Middleman config file: 
```ruby
# Markdown
set :markdown_engine, :redcarpet
set :markdown,
    fenced_code_blocks: true,
    smartypants: true,
    disable_indented_code_blocks: true,
    prettify: true,
    tables: true,
    with_toc_data: true,
    no_intra_emphasis: true

# Sitemap
page "/sitemap.xml", :layout => false

# Assets
set :css_dir, 'stylesheets'
set :js_dir, 'javascripts'
set :images_dir, 'images'
set :fonts_dir, 'fonts'

# Activate the syntax highlighter
activate :syntax

activate :autoprefixer do |config|
  config.browsers = ['last 2 version', 'Firefox ESR']
  config.cascade  = false
  config.inline   = true
end

# Github pages require relative links
activate :relative_assets
set :relative_links, true

# Build Configuration
configure :build do
  # If you're having trouble with Middleman hanging, commenting
  # out the following two lines has been known to help
  activate :minify_css
  activate :minify_javascript
  # activate :relative_assets
  # activate :asset_hash
  # activate :gzip
end

helpers do
  require './lib/toc_data.rb'
end
```

title: Optional Reference-Style Link Space
body:
Markdown allows a space between the square brackets `] [` of a reference style link, but that behavior creates ambiguity and [interference with extensions like task lists](https://github.com/deckar01/task_list/issues/4). --- ### Reference > You can optionally use a space to separate the sets of brackets: > > ```md > This is [an example] [id] reference-style link. > ``` > > http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax#link --- ### Ambiguity ```md [red] [blue] [red]: /red [blue]: /blue ``` Red Carpet renders this as: ```html red ``` but, other markdown engines (like GitHub Flavored Markdown) have disabled the optional space and render it as: ```html red blue ``` --- ### Interference ```md - [ ] [bug] test - [x] [bug] test [bug]: /bug ``` Extensions like task lists work by filtering list items looking for lines starting with `[ /x/X] `, but Red Carpet will have already transformed them into links: ```html
  • test
  • x test
``` If Red Carpet had a way to disable the optional space the ambiguity would be resolved. ```html
  • [ ] bug test
  • [x] bug test
``` --- ### Proposal Add an option named `reference_space` that defaults to true, that determines if the optional space is recognized.

title: Smartypants converts --> into en dash if comment contains HTML
body: @mbuttler found a (slightly esoteric) bug in https://github.com/lord/slate/issues/715, and I think Smartypants might be causing the problem? Here's a minimal example: ```ruby require "redcarpet" puts Redcarpet::Render::SmartyPants.render("Oh SmartyPants, you're so crazy...") # output: Oh SmartyPants, you’re so crazy… puts Redcarpet::Render::SmartyPants.render("") # output: puts Redcarpet::Render::SmartyPants.render("") # output:

title: List Numbering Discrepancy With Github When Bolding Items
body:
I just wanted to point out a discrepancy between how Redcarpet and Github handle bolding a line in an ordered list. Whenever you enter the following markdown... ```` **1. first** 2. Second 3. Third ```` And try to render it as HTML in Redcarpet, you get the following HTML... ````

1. First

  1. Second
  2. Third

```` This makes the numbering off in that it would go (1, 1, 2) and not (1, 2, 3). However, on Github, it starts the numbering at 2 so that the sequence is correct. ````

1. First

  1. Second
  2. Third

```` It's certainly an edge case, but I just wanted to point it out.

title: Include cell header information in table_cell callback.
body:
Copy flag bitmask logic from html.c to rc_render.c. 
Pass whether or not the cell is a header (th) to the table_cell callback. 
Update readme and render_strip to match.

title: table_cell callback doesn't pass MKD_TABLE_HEADER
body: Forgive my newishness if this is a matter which I've overlooked. This is a snippet of my rb file. ``` class HTML < Redcarpet::Render::HTML include Rouge::Plugins::Redcarpet ... def table_row(content) "" + content + "" end def table_cell(content, alignment) #This part doesn't work. Alignment remains nil for both header and body cells. if alignment === "HEADER" "" + content + "" else "" + content + "" end end ... end ``` In html.c in rndr_tablecell there is code if (flags & MKD_TABLE_HEADER) { BUFPUTSL(ob, "

title: Support for Table Footers
body:
I realize I could simply use HTML, but I'm curious if there has been any consideration for the support of table footers. Perhaps something like:

```markdown
| Expense             | Bridgeport, Chicago | Denpasar, Bali      |
| :------------------ | :------------------ | :------------------ |
| Rent                | $650/mo.            | $216/mo.            |
| Utilities           | $100/mo.            | Included with rent  |
| Cable/Internet      | $60/mo.             | Included with rent  |
| Vehicle[^1]         | $405/mo.            | $55/mo.             |
| Gasoline            | $100/mo.            | $8/mo.              |
| Cellphone/LTE       | $90/mo.             | $15/mo.             |
| Drop-off laundering | $10 + tip per load  | $1.90 per load      |
| Cigarettes          | $12 per pack        | $1.80 per pack      |
| Regular coffee      | $1 per cup          | $0.45 per cup       |
| Water               | Free                | $1.50 per 12 liters |
| "Visa runs"         | N/A                 | $165 bi-monthly     |
| :------------------ | :------------------ | :------------------ |
|                     | $1,428.00           | $382.15             |
```

title: incorrect code block rendering
body:
Sample here:
https://gist.github.com/iperry/f880921f916afa6efdc889892f74d3fe

A numbered list followed immediately by a code block seems to render the block as an inline block instead of a fenced block.

Adding line breaks into the block results in correct rendering.

Adding a line break after the line also results in correct rendering.

title: Duplicated <a> tags when autolinks set to true
body:
When you have `:autolink` set to `true`, when you provide raw `` html tag, it is wrapped but should be ignored. This means, as a result we get:

Sample content http://frontendflow.com

\n" > Redcarpet::Markdown.new(Redcarpet::Render::HTML).render("
") => "
\n" ``` The second and fourth examples above work as I would expect. The first and third do not. Best I can tell, they are also valid ways to write an `hr` tag: http://www.w3schools.com/tags/tag_hr.asp The first (`
`) is the proper way to write it in html5 (https://www.w3.org/TR/html5/grouping-content.html#the-hr-element).

title: Allow arbitrary info strings in fenced code blocks
body:
This is related to https://github.com/vmg/redcarpet/issues/187 but it's a problem with the parser, not the renderer. According to the [CommonMark spec](http://spec.commonmark.org/0.27/#fenced-code-blocks) the only restriction on info strings is that they must not contain backtick characters.

In github's rendering of https://github.com/szeiger/ornate/blob/afd538c599a0e6bb767ac61625ce08f2121f91fd/doc/src/markdown.md all blocks with non-trivial info strings are messed up, the same goes for nested blocks, which may be the same or a different problem.

(I hope this is the right place to file this issue. According to https://github.com/github/markup README files are parsed with redcarpet. Note that when pasting the offending Markdown content into a github issue and clicking "Preview", it is parsed correctly.)

title: some tables rendered in incorrect way
body:
Hi,

I have a problem with some tables but I can't understand it is RedCarpet bug or not. You can see attached file [core.req.txt](https://github.com/vmg/redcarpet/files/643725/core.req.txt) that have few tables and incorrect rendering. The first table renders as correct table, the second doesn't.

I use followed options `{ autolink: true, tables: true, with_toc_data: true, fenced_code_blocks: true }`

Before I started [my own simple server](https://github.com/nvoynov/minireq-site) to serve my markdown documents, I used gitbook and didn't have any issues with tables.

title: New lines cause parsing errors
body:
This is a particularly weird bug. I've reproduced it using 3.3.4 under Ruby 2.2.5. `````` ruby def markdown_extensions { autolink: true, # turn any URL into a link space_after_headers: true, # so #Title won't work, # Title will no_intra_emphasis: true, # foo_bar_baz will not generate tags fenced_code_blocks: true, # ``` to start & end code blocks, ```ruby works tables: true, # parse Markdown tables, the best thing ever disable_indented_code_blocks: true, # use triple ``` footnotes: true } end def parser Redcarpet::Markdown.new(Redcarpet::Render::HTML.new, markdown_extensions) end s1 = "# header 1 ## header 2\n - item 1\n - item 2" s2 = "# header 1 \n ## header 2\n - item 1\n - item 2" parser.render s1 => "

header 1 ## header 2

\n\n
    \n
  • item 1
    • \n
  • item 2
    • \n
\n" parser.render s2 => "

header 1

\n\n

## header 2\n - item 1\n - item 2

\n" ``````

title: Assertion failed: `(md->work_bufs[BUFFER_SPAN].size == 0)` - Thread safety related?
body:
First off, thanks for an amazing gem!

I did come across a glitch... I think.

I was testing the rendering system under high stress.

I ran the system in multi threaded mode (running on 16 threads).

While testing, I disabled my own [cache management](https://github.com/boazsegev/plezi/blob/890694ffe725eea99c4ca192e821455025012031/lib/plezi/render/markdown.rb#L53) to stress test the rendering engine (rather then the caching system which was storing the rendered string).

I repeatedly asked for the same file to be rendered. 12 threads were doing the asking, 16 threads were doing the rendering, it was all running through Iodine's async IO using HTTP requests, about 200 concurrent requests at a time.

Every time I ran the test, my server would crash with the error:

> Assertion failed: (md->work_bufs[BUFFER_SPAN].size == 0), function sd_markdown_render, file markdown.c, line 2898

I'm not complaining about the server crashing, I think it's the right thing to do when experiencing data corruption, but I am worried about the underline cause and the risk of production time failures.

I'm assuming this is multi-threading related, since I didn't get the error in single thread mode.

The following is just my guess (my 2Â¢) and I hope this helps track down the issue:

At first look, the C code doesn't seem to exit the Global VM Lock, so I thought I might be wrong, however, after a quick read through the code (that's a lot of code and very nicely written, wow), I think the issue is with the markdown struct storing stateful rendering data.

I believe that `md->refs` and `md->work_bufs` are susceptible to corruption. It also seems to me that these could be separated from the markdown engine into a separate "state struct", so that multi-threaded rendering with the same markdown render engine wouldn't cause data corruption.

I'm thankful for your time and hope for a fix or a workaround.

title: Links bounded with angle brackets get doubly linkified
body:
Hello! When a link is specified with angle brackets around a URL as the link text, the link gets doubly linkified and the real target becomes that of the description, rather than the markdown-specified target. ``` ruby require 'redcarpet' renderer = Redcarpet::Render::HTML.new() markdown = Redcarpet::Markdown.new(renderer, {}) puts markdown.render('[](https://google.com)')

http://test.com/

``` The two nested `` tags result take the user to `test.com` when they click on the linked text. It looks like this is happening because it's autolinking `` after generating the initial link. Am I correct in assuming this is undesirable behaviour? Let me know if there's anything I can help with!

title: Comments in Unordered Lists
body:
Sometimes I want to comment out a bullet without removing from the source

```
* Bullet #1
<!-- * Bullet #2 -->
* Bullet #3
```

This results in 
- Bullet #1 <!-- Bullet #2 -->
- Bullet #3

Why are the comments rendered when in an unordered list and not when they are their own paragraph?

title: Empty string title breaks reference style link
body:
```
# works right:
[Google]: https://google.com/ "This is a link to Google"

# broken:
[Google]: https://google.com/ ""
```

The reason this is an issue is that some programs (Emacs' markdown-mode in this case) auto generate reference links with empty strings like this if they aren't explicitly given a title. I debated making an issue for markdown-mode or making an issue here, but it seems like this is an edge case that should not break the rendering of the markdown, regardless.
